item.title: Embedded Gists
item.description:
Syntax Highlighting - or Embedded Gists

I was quite excited by the inline syntax highlighting that Hugo provides via the python plugin Pygments. But also wanted to try embedding gists

So here is an example…

def digit_sum(n): s = 0 while n: # while n is ‘truthy’ for an integer that means not 0 s = s + (n % 10) # the sum is the sum + the remainder of dividing the incoming number (n) by 10 157 % 10 = 7 n = n / 10 # n = the integer of n / 10 int(15.7) = 15 return s

print digit_sum(157)

”’ calling digit_sum(157)

loop | s | n | n % 10 | n / 10

0 | 0 | 157 | 7 | 15 1 | 7 | 15 | 5 | 1 2 | 12 | 1 | 1 | 0 3 | 13 | 0 | |
”’

But then thought perhaps it is better to embed gists than have inline markup in blog posts then folk can fork the code and comment there.

So on embedding a gist as follows (but without syntax highlighting) failed…

Putting it in another block partially worked

I was left with an unclosed script tag.

A git of googling turned up this thread…

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/hugo-discuss/3GW56aMYQF8

and this pull request …

https://github.com/spf13/hugo/pull/305

which missed the latest release by a few days…

https://github.com/spf13/hugo/releases/tag/v0.11

So I went ahead an built the master head - from my fork (ya know just in case I can help)

and added the script tag in….

And it worked !

Nice work jmitchell and Steve Francia.

So gists it is for me

item.title: Making Your Own Summary
item.description:
Hugo allows you to specify where the summary stops - and allows the full markdown including shortcodes.

You just need to construct the first bit of your article so that it makes a nice summary and then end it with…

< !--more-->

(of course dont include the space :) )

Everything after the more comment will not make it into the summary - sweet.

item.title: Moving to Hugo
item.description:
I decided that I should blog under my danmux.com domain - I often use danmux around the internet, sometimes danmull, but normally danmux for tech type things, so it makes sense.

danmux because the x has always been a notable part of my name - and mux reminds me of my electrical engineering days, and I think humans multiplex all the time, there it is.

Github Pages

As this will only get a couple of hits what could be better than hosting it on github pages - I’m a little bit in love with github anyway so perfect choice.

Hugo

I’m a little bit in love with go - so Hugo was the perfect choice as well, and its been great so far, other than is typical of newish open source projects slightly lacking in the documentation department.
